citation.abstract: A persistent dialkylsilanone was synthesized by the dehydrobromination of a dialkylbromosilanol with tris(trimethylsilyl)silyl potassium in solution at -80 °C: It was characterized by NMR and IR spectroscopy, and was tested in several reactions. In (29) Si NMR spectrum in [D8 ]toluene, the signal due to the unsaturated silicon nuclei was observed at 128.7 ppm. Reactions of the dialkylsilanone with water and mesitonitrile oxide gave a silanediol and a [2+3] cycloadduct, respectively. The silanone remains intact in [D8 ]toluene below -80 °C for at least two days, while it undergoes unprecedented isomerization to give a siloxysilene by means of 1,3-silyl migration at higher temperatures.
citation.title: Persistent Dialkylsilanone Generated by Dehydrobromination of Dialkylbromosilanol

facebook.title: Persistent Dialkylsilanone Generated by Dehydrobromination of Dialkylbromosilanol - Ishida -...
facebook.summary:
Better than carbonyl

Silicon–oxygen doubly bonded compounds (silanones) have
been an attractive species, as silicon versions of carbonyl compounds, since the beginning of silicon chemistry.

In their Communication, now available on Early View, S. Ishida,
